DOC.HEAD: Crews Plug Leaking LPG Barge, Evacuees Return Home
DOC.TEXT: Crews plugged a howling, high-pressure leak in a barge loaded with 16,500 barrels of liquefied petroleum gas Tuesday, and officials let about 2,000 evacuees return home. About 45 square blocks of northern Houma, including three schools, were evacuated Monday afternoon after the barge hit a bridge on the Intracoastal Waterway, which runs through this south Louisiana city, and began to leak. There were no injuries in the accident and the bridge was not damaged, but the leak, howling from a broken 2{-inch pipe leading to one of four holds on the barge, was audible a mile from the accident site. Jim Drone, lawyer for the barge owner, Hollywood Marine of Houston, said the vessel carried about 16,500 barrels, or 693,000 gallons of LNG, but the amount lost won't be known until the cargo is off-loaded at a repair yard. The Coast Guard closed part of the waterway to navigation until 9 a.m. Tuesay. Authorities said the barge was loaded at the Shell refinery in Norco and was bound for Victoria, Texas, when the accident occurred.
